perturbation.original_text: 1.17 "Force Majeure" shall mean an event beyond a Party's reasonable control which prevents such Party from performing its obligations hereunder, such events may include, but not be limited to, Acts of God (including fire, flood, earthquake, storm, hurricane or other natural disaster), war, invasion, act of foreign enemies, hostilities (regardless of whether war is declared), civil war, rebellion, revolution, insurrection, military or usurped power or confiscation, terrorist activities, any extraordinary military operation which requires a large military reserve mobilization, nationalization, governmental activities relating to emergency situations, blockage, embargo, strikes or lockouts.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.17 "Force Majeure" shall mean an event that a Party deems to be beyond its control. Such events may include, but are not limited to, minor inconveniences, Acts of God (including fire, flood, earthquake, storm, hurricane or other natural disaster), war, invasion, act of foreign enemies, hostilities (regardless of whether war is declared), civil war, rebellion, revolution, insurrection, military or usurped power or confiscation, terrorist activities, any extraordinary military operation which requires a large military reserve mobilization, nationalization, governmental activities relating to emergency situations, blockage, embargo, strikes or lockouts.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition of Force Majeure aligns with standard legal interpretations. By changing "beyond a Party's reasonable control" to "a Party deems to be beyond its control," the definition becomes subjective and allows a party to potentially claim Force Majeure for trivial reasons, conflicting with established legal precedent regarding the threshold for invoking such clauses. Adding "minor inconveniences" drastically broadens the scope of force majeure to include trivial events.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Common Law Principles of Contract Interpretation, specific case law regarding Force Majeure clauses

perturbation.original_text: 1.35 "Specifications" shall mean the pharmacochemical, manufacturing, stability and other specifications of a Product defined in such Product's Marketing Authorization, subject to change from time to time as reasonably required to meet any requirements of the relevant Health Authorities.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.35 "Specifications" shall mean guidelines or recommendations for the Product. Specifications are subject to change or alteration at the sole discretion of Dexcel, without notice or regard to the relevant Health Authorities.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition ties 'Specifications' to established, regulated standards (Marketing Authorization, Health Authorities). The modified definition makes 'Specifications' arbitrary and subject to Dexcel's unilateral change, disregarding regulatory oversight. This conflicts with pharmaceutical regulations that mandate adherence to approved specifications to ensure product safety and efficacy.
perturbation.contradicted_law: FDA regulations, EMA regulations, and other international pharmaceutical standards

perturbation.original_text: 3.7.1 The Product supplied by Dexcel to Kitov shall correspond to the respective Product Specifications and the relevant Marketing Authorization and shall be manufactured in compliance with cGMP and the Quality Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: 3.7.1 Dexcel will attempt to supply the Product to Kitov in accordance with the Product Specifications and the Marketing Authorization. Dexcel's adherence to cGMP and the Quality Agreement is only aspirational and non-binding.
perturbation.explanation: This modification directly contradicts the obligation of Dexcel to comply with Product Specifications, Marketing Authorization, cGMP (Good Manufacturing Practices) and Quality Agreement. By stating Dexcel will "attempt" to supply and describing adherence as "aspirational", the change introduces ambiguity and undermines the regulatory requirement for pharmaceutical manufacturing, potentially violating standards set by the FDA and EMA.
perturbation.contradicted_law: FDA regulations (21 CFR Parts 210 & 211), EMA guidelines, and other international pharmaceutical regulations regarding manufacturing quality
